refnamediv.refpurpose: Invokes the Cray C++ compiler, the Cray C compiler, or the Cray C language preprocessor

refsect1.title: foobar
refsect1.para:
This man page describes the following commands:
CC. This command invokes the Cray C++ compiler on source files that contain C++ code. The Cray C++ compiler conforms to the ISO/IEC 14882:1998 standard, with some exceptions. The exceptions are noted in the foobar.
cc, c89, and c99. These commands invoke the Cray C compiler and the source preprocessor on source files that contain C code. The compiler conforms to the ISO/IEC 9899:1999 and to the American National Standards Institute (ANSI) X3.159foobar1989 standards.
cpp. This command invokes only the preprocessor component of the Cray C compiler. The cpp command optionally accepts two file names as arguments. Files infile and outfile are, respectively, the input and output for the preprocessor. If not specified, they default to standard input (stdin) and standard output (stdout).
By default, the Cray C and C++ compilers create an executable file named a.out. Other files used and created by the C++ and C compilers are discussed under the FILES section of this man page.

refsect2.title: Conflicting Options
refsect2.para: If conflicting options are specified, the option specified last on the command line overrides the previously specified option. Exceptions to this rule are noted in the individual option descriptions.

refsect2.title: Conflicts between Options and #pragma Directives
refsect2.para: Most #pragma directives override corresponding command-line options. For example, #pragmafoobar_CRIfoobarnovsearch overrides the -hfoobarvsearch option. #pragmafoobar_CRIfoobarnovsearch also overrides the -hfoobarvsearch option implied by the -hfoobarvector2 or -O2 option. Exceptions to this rule are noted in option or #pragma directive descriptions.

refsect2.title: Arguments to the -h Option
refsect2.para: The arguments to the -h option can be used to direct specific compiler actions. To specify more than one argument, separate individual arguments with commas but without intervening spaces. The -h option is available only to the CC, cc, and c99 commands, unless otherwise specified in the option description.

refsect2.title: Command-line Options
refsect2.para: The CC, cc, c89, c99, and cpp commands accept many of the same options. If you enter an option that is not accepted by a particular command, a message is generated. Other options are interpreted as loader options. See the man page for loader options.

The CC, cc, c89, c99, and cpp compiler commands accept the following options, which are grouped according to functionality:
The compiler commands that support the option are listed within parentheses, if an option is supported by some of the commands. If all compiler commands support the option, the commands are not listed.

listitem.para: The -h c99 option allows the compiler to accept features added to the ISO/IEC 9899:1999 C Language standard (C99). Several of these features supported in earlier Cray compilers, previously documented as extensions, do not require the -h noc99 option.
The default is -h noc99 for cc and -h c99 for c99.

-hfoobarconform (CC and cc commands) and -hfoobarstdc (cc and c99 commands) specify strict conformance to the ISO C or ISO C++ standards as supported. -hfoobarnoconform and -hfoobarnostdc (the defaults) specify partial conformance to the standards. The -hfoobarexceptions, -hfoobardep_name, and -hfoobarparse_templates options are enabled by the -hfoobarconform option in C++.

note.para: The c89 command does not accept the -hfoobarconform or -hfoobarstdc option when issued on the command line. It is enabled by default when the command is issued.

listitem.para: (CC command) Causes the Cray C++ compiler to accept constructs that were accepted by previous cfront-based compilers (such as Cray C++ 1.0), but which are not accepted by the ANSI/ISO draft standard.
This feature is disabled by default.

(CC command) The option noparse_templates allows existing code that defines templates using previous versions (before Programming Environment 3.6) of the Cray Standard Template Library (STL) to compile successfully with the -h conform option. This allows you to compile existing code without having to use the Cray C++ STL. The compiler also defaults to this mode when the -h dep_name option is used. To have the compiler verify that your code uses the Cray C++ STL templates properly, use the parse_templates option. The default is -h noparse_templates.

(CC command) The -hfoobarnodep_name option allows dependent names that rely on nonstandard STLs to compile when the -hfoobarconform option is used. The -hfoobardep_name option cannot be used with the -hfoobarnoparse_templates option. The default is -hfoobarnodep_name.

(CC command) Enables or disables exception handling. -hfoobarnoexceptions issues an error whenever an exception construct, a try block, a throw expression, or a throw specification on a function declaration is encountered. -hfoobarexceptions is enabled by -hfoobarconform. The default is exceptions, however, if the CRAYOLDCPPLIB environment variable is set to a nonzero value, the default is noexceptions.
(CC command) Enables or disables anachronisms in Cray C++. See Appendix B of the foobar for a description of anachronisms. The default is noanachronisms. This option is overridden by -hfoobarconform.

(CC command) The -h new_for_init option enables the new scoping rules for a declaration in a for-init statement. This means that the new (standard-conforming) rules are in effect and that the entire for statement is wrapped in its own implicitly generated scope. -hfoobarnew_for_init is implied by the -hfoobarconform option.

(cc and c99 commands) Allows older, less standard C constructs to facilitate porting of code written for previous C compilers. Errors involving comparisons or assignments of pointers and integers become warnings. The compiler generates casts so that the types agree. With notolerant, the compiler is intolerant of the older constructs. The default is notolerant.

The use of the -h tolerant options causes the compiler to tolerate accessing an object with one type through a pointer to an entirely different type. For example, a pointer to long might be used to access an object declared with type double. Such references violate the C standard and should be eliminated if possible. They can reduce the effectiveness of alias analysis, thereby inhibiting optimization.
(CC command) The -h no const_string_literals options controls whether string literals are const (as required by the standard) or non-const (as was true in earlier versions of the C++ language).
(CC and cc commands) The -h gnu option enables the compiler to recognize a subset of the GCC version 3.3.2 extensions to C listed in Table 1. Table 2 lists the extensions that apply only to C++.
See GCC documentation for detailed descriptions of the GCC C and C++ language extensions.

listitem.para: (CC command) Enables simple template instantiation by the Cray C++ compiler. For more information on simple template instantiation, see the foobar The default is autoinstantiate.

(CC command) Enables or disables prelinker (automatic) instantiation of templates by the Cray C++ compiler. For more information on automatic instantiation, see the foobar The default is autoinstantiate.

(CC command) Put each template object referenced in the source into a separate object file for instantiation. The primary object file will contain everything else that is not a template object. See the -h instantiation_dir option for the location of the object files.

(CC command) Specify the instantiation directory that the -h one_instantiation_per_object option should use. If the directory does not exist, it will be created if possible. The default directory is ./Template.dir.

(CC command) Sets the mode for instantiation of templates. Typically, no templates are instantiated during compilation of a source file except those assigned to the file by automatic instantiation. The default is instantiate=none. To change the overall instantiation mode, specify one of the following for mode: none
Default. Does not automatically create instantiations of any template entities. This is the most appropriate mode when prelinker (automatic) instantiation is enabled.
used
Instantiates only those template entities that were used in the compilation. This includes all static data members that have template definitions.
all
Instantiates all template functions declared or referenced in the compilation unit. For each fully instantiated template class, all of its member functions and static data members are instantiated regardless of whether they were used. Nonmember template functions are instantiated even if the only reference was a declaration.
local
Similar to instantiate=used except that the functions are given internal linkage. This mode provides a simple mechanism for those who are not familiar with templates. The compiler instantiates the functions used in each compilation unit as local functions, and the program links and runs correctly (barring problems due to multiple copies of local static variables). This mode may generate multiple copies of the instantiated functions and is not suitable for production use. This mode cannot be used in conjunction with prelinker (automatic) template instantiation. Automatic template instantiation is disabled by this mode.
If CC is given a single source file to compile and link, all instantiations are done in the single source file and, by default, the instantiate=used mode is used to suppress prelinker instantiation.

(CC command) Enables or disables implicit inclusion of source files as a method of finding definitions of template entities to be instantiated. The default is implicitinclude. For more information on template instantiation, see the foobar.
(CC command) Causes the prelinker to recompile all the sources to remove all instantiation flags.
(CC command) Indicates that only local files (for example, files in the current directory) are candidates for assignment of instantiations.
(CC command) Causes the assignment of an instantiation to a nonlocal object file to result in the object file being recompiled in the current directory.

(CC command) The virtual function table for a class is defined in a compilation if the compilation contains a definition of the first noninline, nonpure virtual function of the class. There are cases in which heuristic methods used by the compiler front end to decide on definition of virtual function tables provide no guidance. In these cases, specifying forcevtbl forces the definition of virtual definition tables. The forcevtbl option differs from the default behavior in that it does not force the definition to be local.
The suppressvtbl argument suppresses definition of virtual function tables.
By default, the compiler defines the virtual function table as a local static entity.
See the description for forcevtbl.

(CC command) When specified, the static constructor/destructor .o file is retained as file. This option is useful when linking .o files on a system that does not have a C++ compiler. To use this option, the static constructor/destructor file must be included in the link. Following this precaution, mixed object files (files with .o suffixes) from C and C++ compilations can be linked into executables by using the loader command for your system. By default, the static constructor/destructor file is not created. Without this option, the program must be linked with the CC command to ensure that static construction/destruction is done.

Globally instructs the compiler to treat certain classes of pointers as restricted pointers. You can use this option to enhance optimization, including vectorization. Enter one of the following for args: a
All pointers to object and incomplete types are to be considered restricted pointers, regardless of where they appear in the source code. This includes pointers in struct, union, and class declarations, type casts, function prototypes, and so on.
Do not specify restrict=a if, during execution of any function, an object is modified and that object is referenced through either two different pointers or through the declared name of the object and a pointer. Undefined behavior may result.
f
All function parameters that are pointers to objects or incomplete types are to be considered restricted pointers.
CAUTION: Do not specify restrict=f if, during execution of any function, an object is modified and that object is referenced through either two different pointer function parameters or through the declared name of the object and a pointer function parameter. Undefined behavior may result.
t
CC command. All this pointers are to be considered restricted pointers.
Do not specify restrict=t if, during execution of any function, an object is modified and that object is referenced through the declared name of the object and a this pointer. Undefined behavior may result.

These arguments instruct the compiler to assume that, in the current compilation unit, each pointer (=a), or each pointer that is a function parameter (=f), or each this pointer (=t) points to a unique object. This assumption eliminates those pointers as sources of potential aliasing and may allow additional vectorization or other optimizations. These options cause only data dependencies from pointer aliasing to be ignored, rather than all data dependencies, so they can be used safely for more programs than the -hfoobarivdep option.

Permits use of @ and $ in identifier names. This option is useful for porting codes in which identifiers include these characters. With nocalchars (the default), these characters are not allowed in identifier names.

caution.para: Identifiers with these characters are within Cray name space and are included in many Cray library identifiers, internal compiler labels, objects, and functions. You must prevent conflicts between any of these uses, current or future, and identifier declarations or references in your code; any such conflict is an error.

listitem.para: Affects the result of the right shift operator. For the expression e1foobar>>foobare2 where e1 has a signed type and signedshifts is in effect, the vacated bits are filled with the sign bit of e1. When nosignedshifts is in effect, the vacated bits are filled with zeros, identical to the behavior when e1 has an unsigned type.

Used when compiling source files containing subprograms that will be called from streamed regions, whether those streamed regions are created by CSD directives or by the use of the ssp_private or concurrent directives to cause autostreaming.

The -h aggress option provides greater opportunity to optimize loops that would otherwise by inhibited from optimization due to an internal compiler size limitation. -h noaggress leaves this size limitation in effect.
With -hfoobaraggress, internal compiler tables are expanded to accommodate larger loop bodies. This option can increase the compilation's time and memory size.
The default is -h noaggress.
Displays the current optimization settings for this compilation.

The Globally allows or disallows loop fusion. By default, the compiler attempts to fuse all loops, unless the foobarh nofusion option is specified. Fusing loops generally increases single processor performance by reducing memory traffic and loop overhead. On rare occasions loop fusing may degrade performance.

note.para: Loop fusion is disabled when the vectorization level is set to 0 or 1.

listitem.para: Refer to foobar for more information about loop fusion.

Allows the use of intrinsic hardware functions, which allow direct access to some Cray hardware instructions or generate inline code for some functions. The default is intrinsics. This option has no effect on specially handled library functions. See the foobar for a complete list of intrinsic functions.
Allows the creation of loopmark listings. The values for opt are:
Use all list options
Add page breaks to listing
Expand include files
Intersperse optimization messages within the source listing rather than at the end
Create loopmark listing
Create a complete source listing (include files not expanded)
Create a wide listing rather than the default of 80 characters

Causes the compiler to generate code and to select the appropriate libraries to create an executable that runs on one or more multistreaming processors (MSP mode). Any code, including Cray memory models, can use MSP mode. Default.
Executables compiled for MSP mode can use object files compiled with MSP or SSP mode.
For more information about MSP mode, refer to foobar. For information about SSP mode, see the -h ssp option.
Globally enables or disables pattern matching. Pattern matching is enabled by default, but it only takes effect when -hfoobarscalar2 or higher is specified. The default is pattern.

The -h overindex option declares that there are array subscripts that index a dimension of an array that is outside the declared bounds of that array. The -hfoobarnooverindex option declares that there are no array subscripts that index a dimension of an array that is outside the declared bounds of that array.
The default is -h nooverindex.

Causes the compiler to compile the code and select the appropriate libraries to create an executable that runs on a single-streaming processor (SSP mode). Any code, including code that uses Cray parallel programming model constructs, can use SSP mode. The executable runs on one SSP on an application node.

Executables compiled for SSP mode can use only those object files that were compiled in SSP mode. When loading object files separately from the compile step, the SSP mode must be specified during the load step.
Since SSP mode does not use streaming, the compiler automatically uses the -h stream0 option. This causes the compiler to ignore Cray Streaming Directives (CSDs).

note.para: Code explicitly compiled with the -h stream0 option can be linked with object files compiled with MSP or SSP mode. You can use this option to create a universal library that can be used in MSP or SSP mode.

listitem.para: For more information about SSP mode, refer to foobar. For information about MSP mode, see the -h msp option. For information on creating your own commands and running them on a single SSP on the support node, see the -h command option.
This option is off by default.

The foobarh nounroll option globally allows or disallows unrolling of loops. By default, the compiler attempts to all unroll loops, unless the foobarh nounroll option is specified, or the unroll 0 or unroll 1 directive is specified for a loop. Loop unrolling generally increases single processor performance at the cost of increased compile time and code size.
Refer to foobar for more information about loop unrolling.

Specifies the optimization level for a group of compiler features. A value of 0, 1, 2, or 3 sets that level of optimization for each of the -hfoobarinlinen, -hfoobarscalarn, -hfoobarstreamn, and -hfoobarvectorn options.

For example, -O2 is equivalent to -hfoobarinline2,scalar2,stream2,vector2. -O with no argument specified is the same as not specifying the -O option; the default optimization settings are the same as the defaults for the individual -h options.

The -hfoobarstreamn option specifies the level of automatic MSP optimizations to be performed. Generally, vectorized applications that execute on a one-processor system can expect to execute up to four times faster on a processor with multistreaming enabled.
These can be used for the n argument:
No automatic multistreaming optimizations are performed.

Conservative automatic multistreaming optimizations. Automatic multistreaming optimization is limited to inner vectorized loops and some bit matrix multiplication (BMM) operations. MSP operations performed generate the same results that would be obtained from scalar optimizations; for example, no floating-point reductions are performed. This level is compatible with -h vector1, 2, and 3.
Moderate automatic multistreaming optimizations. Automatic multistreaming optimization is performed on loop nests and appropriate BMM operations. This level is compatible with -h vector2 and 3.
Aggressive automatic multistreaming optimizations. Automatic multistreaming optimization is performed as with stream2. This level is compatible with -h vector2 and 3.

(CC, cc, and c99 commands) Instructs the compiler to assume an infinite safe vector length for all #pragma ivdep directives. The -h noinfinitevl option instructs the compiler to assume a safe vector length equal to 64 for all #pragma ivdep directives.
The default is -h infinitevl.

Instructs the compiler to ignore vector dependencies for all loops. This is useful for vectorizing loops that contain pointers. With noivdep, loop dependencies inhibit vectorization; this is the default. To control loops individually, use the ivdep directive.
The -h ivdep option severely constrains other loop optimizations and should be avoided if at all possible.
CAUTION: Incorrect results can occur if there is a vector dependency within a loop. Combining this option with inlining is dangerous because inlining can introduce vector dependencies.

Specifies the level of automatic vectorization to be performed. Vectorization results in dramatic performance improvements with a small increase in executable size. Vectorization directives are unaffected by this option. The default is -hfoobarvector2. Enter one of the following for n: n
Vectorization Level
0
No automatic vectorization.
1
Conservative automatic vectorization on inner loops only. Automatic vectorization is performed. Floating-point reduction loops are not vectorized.
2
Moderate automatic vectorization. Automatic vectorization as with vector1 and vectorization of reduction loops is added. Loop nests are restructured, and vectorization can be applied to any loop in the nest. Default.
3
Aggressive automatic vectorization. Automatic vectorization is performed as with vector2. The aliasing assumptions specified in the standard are used (for example, it is assumed that no aliasing will occur between two pointers to different structure types).
Vectorizes search loops. With novsearch, the default vectorization level applies. This option is affected by the -h vectorn option. The default option is -hfoobarvsearch.

Specifies the level of inlining to be performed. Inlining eliminates the overhead of a function call and increases the opportunities for other optimizations. Inlining can also increase object code size. Inlining directives and the inline keyword are unaffected by this option. The default is -hfoobarinline2. Enter one of the following values for n: 0
No inlining is performed.
1
Conservative inlining. Inlining is performed only on functions marked by the inline keyword, on functions marked by the #pragmafoobar_CRIfoobarinline directive, or on functions defined inside a class definition.
2
Same function as level 1 except that it has a different threshold (the maximum code space and execution time allowed)
3
Aggressive automatic inlining. All functions are candidates for inlining except those specifically marked with a #pragmafoobarnoinline directive.

(CC, cc, and c99 commands) The -h interchange option allows the compiler to attempt to interchange all loops. Interchanging loops is a technique that is used to gain performance by having the compiler swap an inner loop with an outer loop. The compiler attempts the interchange only if the interchange is judged by the compiler to increase performance. Loop interchange is done only at scalar optimization level 2 or higher.
The -h nointerchange option prohibits the compiler from attempting to interchange any loops. To disable interchange of loops individually, use the #pragma nointerchange directive.

Specifies the level of automatic scalar optimization to be performed. Scalar optimization directives are unaffected by this option. The default is -hfoobarscalar1. Enter one of the following for n: 0
No automatic scalar optimization. The matherror=errno and zeroinc options are enabled when -hfoobarscalar0 is specified.
1
Default. Conservative automatic scalar optimization. The matherror=abort and zeroinc arguments are enabled when -hfoobarscalar1 is specified.
2
Moderate automatic scalar optimization.
3
Aggressive automatic scalar optimization.
The reduction option causes the compiler to vectorize all reduction loops. This option is disabled by the -h scalar0 and enabled by -h scalar1, 2 or 3.
Default is -h reduction.

Improves run-time performance by causing the compiler to assume that constant increment variables (CIVs) in loops are not incremented by expressions with the value of 0. zeroinc causes the compiler to assume that some constant increment variables in loops might be incremented by 0 for each pass through the loop, preventing generation of optimized code. The default is nozeroinc.

Offers finer control over floating-point optimizations than the -h [no]ieeeconform option. The n argument controls the level of optimization; 0 indicates minimum freedom to optimize floating-point operations, while 3 indicates maximum. The higher the optimization level, the lesser the conformance to the IEEE standard for floating point.
Valid values for n range from 0 through 3. Level 0 is equivalent to foobarh ieeeconform.
The default is foobarh fp2.

(CC and cc) Enforces closer conformance to the IEEE floating-point standard (ANSI/IEEE Std 754-1985). ieeeconform causes the resulting executable code to conform more closely to the standard. Use of this option disables many arithmetic identity optimizations and may result in significantly slower code. noieeeconform causes the compiler to optimize expressions such as xfoobar!=foobarx to 0 and x/x to 1, where x has floating type. With ieeeconform in effect, these, and other similar identity optimizations, are not performed. Optimizations on integral types are not affected by this option.
The default is noieeeconform.

Specifies the method of error processing used if a standard math function encounters an error. The default is matherror=abort. Enter one of the following for method: abort
If an error is detected, errno is not set. A message is issued and the program aborts. On Cray systems with IEEE floating-point hardware, an exception may be raised.
errno
If an error is detected, errno is set and the math function returns to the caller. The -hfoobarconform option enables matherror=errno.

(CC, cc, and c99 commands) Generates debugging information that is used by symbolic debuggers such as . This allows you to set breakpoints when you are debugging. Specify one of the following for level:
level
Optimization
Breakpoints allowed on
f
Fully optimized debugging
Function entry and exit
p
Partially optimized debugging
Block boundaries and labels
n
No optimized debugging
Every executable statement
More extensive debugging levels (such as full) permit greater optimization opportunities for the compiler. Debugging at any level may inhibit some optimization techniques such as inlining.

The debugging options take precedence over any conflicting options appearing on the command line. If more than one debugging option appears on the command line, the last one specified takes precedence.

(CC, cc, c89, and c99 commands) This option is equivalent to specifying -Gn. The -g option is included for compatibility with earlier versions of the compiler and many other UNIX systems; the -G option is the preferred specification. The -g and -Gn options disable all optimizations and imply -O0.
This option is included for compatibility with earlier versions of the compiler and many other UNIX systems; see the -G option for the preferred specification.

(cc and c99 commands) Checks pointer and array references to ensure that they are within acceptable boundaries. The pointer check verifies that the pointer is greater than 0 and less than the machine memory limit. The array check verifies that the subscript is greater than or equal to 0 and is less than the array size, if declared. The nobounds argument disables these checks. The default is nobounds.
The -h zero option causes stack-allocated memory to be initialized to all zeros.

Specifies the lowest level of severity of messages to be issued. Messages at the specified level and above are issued. The default is -hfoobarmsglevel_3. Enter one of the following for n: 0
Comment
1
Note
2
Caution
3
Warning (Default)
4
Error

Enables or disables specified compiler messages. n is the number of the message to be enabled or disabled. You can specify more than one message number; multiple numbers must be separated by a colon with no intervening spaces. By default, all messages at the WARNING and ERROR levels are enabled. For example, to disable messages cc-172 and cc-65, specify the following: -hfoobarnomessage=172:65

This option overrides the -hfoobarmsglevel_n option for the specified messages. If n is not a valid message number, it is ignored. Any compiler message except ERROR, INTERNAL, and LIMIT messages can be disabled. Attempts to disable these messages using the -hfoobarnomessage=n option are ignored.

Generates optimization messages specified by args and lets you direct the specified messages to a file. By default, no optimization messages are generated. Enter one or more of the following for args: args
Type of Messages Generated
i
Inlining optimization messages.
m
Generates multistreaming optimization messages.
s
Scalar optimization messages.
v
Vector optimization messages.
f
Specified messages are written to file.V, where file is the source file specified on the command line. When the cc or c99 command is used, messages are written to stdout if the f option is not specified. When the CC command is used, messages are written to stderr if the f option is not specified.

If specifying multiple args, enter them without intervening spaces or separators. No spaces are allowed around the equal sign (=) or any of the args codes. For example, the following command prints inlining and scalar optimization messages:cc -h report=is myfile.c
Controls whether the compilation aborts if an error is detected. The default is noabort.

Specifies the maximum number of error messages the compiler writes before it exits. n is a positive integer. Setting errorlimit=0 disables exiting on the basis of the number of errors. -hfoobarerrorlimit with no qualifier is equivalent to setting n equal to 1. The default for Cray C++ is -hfoobarerrorlimit=100. The default for Cray C is -hfoobarerrorlimit=70.

Initiates preprocessor activity, as follows:
If the -E option is specified on the cc, CC, c89, or c99 command line, only the preprocessor phase of the compiler is invoked. On these commands, the -E and -P options are equivalent except that -E directs output to stdout and inserts appropriate #line preprocessing directives. The -E option takes precedence over the -h feonly, -S, or -c options.
When the -E option is specified on the cpp command line, it inserts the appropriate #line directives in the preprocessed output. When both -P and -E are specified, the last option specified takes precedence.

(CC, cc, c99, and cpp) When -P is specified on the CC, cc, or c99 command line, it executes only the preprocessor phase of the compiler for each source file specified. The preprocessed output for each source file is written to a file with a name that corresponds to the name of the source file and has .i suffix substituted for the suffix of the source file. -P is similar to -E, except that #line directives are suppressed and the preprocessed source does not go to stdout. -P takes precedence over -h feonly, -S, and -c.
When -p is specified by itself on the cpp command line, it is ignored. When both -P and -E are specified, the last option specified takes precedence.

(CC, cc, and c99 commands) Limits the compiler to syntax checking only. The optimizer and code generator are not executed. This option takes precedence over the -S and -c options. This feature is disabled by default.

(cc, c99, and CC) Compiles the named C or C++ source files and leaves their assembly language output in the corresponding files suffixed with .s. This option overrides the -c option. If this option is specified with the -G or -g option, debugging information is not generated.

(CC, cc, c89, and c99 commands) Creates a relocatable object file for each named source file, but does not link the object files. The relocatable object file name corresponds to the name of the source file; a .o suffix is substituted for the suffix of the source file.
(CC, cc, c99, and cpp commands) Produces output indicating each phase of the compilation as it is executed. Each succeeding output line overwrites the previous line.
(CC, cc, c99, and cpp commands) Produces output indicating each phase of the compilation, as well as all options and arguments being passed to each phase, as they are executed.
(CC, cc, c99, and cpp commands) Same as -##, except the compilation phases are not executed.

(CC, cc, and c99 commands) Passes arguments directly to a phase of the compiling system. The phase indicates system phases as follows:
phase
System phase
Command
p
Preprocessor
cpp
0
Compiler foobar
CC, cc, and c99
a
Assembler
as(1)
l
Loader
ld(1)

Arguments to be passed to system phases must be entered according to the following rules:
If spaces appear within a string to be passed, the string must be enclosed in quotation marks ("string"). If quotation marks are not used, spaces cannot appear in strings. For example, the following command line sends -e name and -s to the loader: cc -Wl,"-e name -s" file.c
Commas can appear wherever spaces normally appear. An option and its arguments can be separated either by a comma or not separated. If a comma is part of an argument, it must be preceded by the backslash (\e) character. For example, either of the following command lines sends -e name and -s to the loader: cc -Wl,-e,name,-s file.c cc -Wl,"-e name",-s file.c
Because the preprocessor is built into the compiler, -Wp and -W0 are equivalent.

Specifies a new directory (dirname) from which the designated phase should be executed. phase accepts the same values as the -W option's phase argument. Because there is no separate preprocessor, -Yp and -Y0 are equivalent. p is the only phase argument that is allowed on the cpp command line.

(CC, cc, c99, and cpp) Retains all comments in the preprocessed source code, except those on preprocessor directive lines. By default, the preprocessor phase strips comments from the source code. This option is useful with the cpp command or specified in combination with the -P or -E options on the cc, c99, and CC commands.
Defines a macro named macro as if it were defined by a #define directive. If =def argument is not specified, macro is defined as 1. To define more than one macro, specify multiple -D options.

Predefined macros also exist and are described in the foobar. You can use the -D option to redefine any of the predefined macros, except those required by the C and C++ standards. The -U option overrides the -D option if the same macro is specified for both, regardless of the order in which they appear on the command line.

Enables or disables the processing of specified directives in the source code. More than one name can be specified. Multiple name arguments must be separated by a colon without intervening spaces, as in the following example:CC -h pragma=inline:allvector yourfile.C

name can be one of the following: directive
The name of a specific directive. Use care when using this option to enable or disable individual directives. Some directives occur in pairs. For these directives, you must disable both directives if you want to disable either. Otherwise, the disabling of one of the directives may cause errors when the other directive is (or is not) present in the compilation unit.
all
All directives.
allinline
All directives related to inlining (inline and noinline).
allscalar
All directives related to scalar optimization (concurrent, nointerchange, noreduction, suppress, and unroll).
allvector
All directives related to vectorization (ivdep, noreduction, novector, novsearch, prefervector, and shortloop).
By default, no directives are disabled.

Specifies a directory for files named in #include directives. Use this option when the #include file names do not have a specified path. Each directory specified must have a separate -I option. The order in which directories are searched for files named in #include directives is determined by enclosing the file name in either quotation marks ("") or angle brackets (foobar>).

Directories for #include "file" are searched in the following order:
Directory of the input file
Directories named in -I options in command line order
Default directories

Directories for #includefoobarfoobarfile> are searched in the following order:
Directories named in -I options in command line order
Default directories

Default directories are searched in the following order:
Site- and release-specific C++ include file directories
Directory /usr/include

When the -I option specifies a directory name that does not begin with a slash (/) character, the directory is interpreted as relative to the current working directory and not relative to the directory of the input file (if different from the current working directory). For example: cc -I. -I yourdir mydir/b.c

The preceding command line produces the following search order:
mydir (#include using quotation marks " only)
Current working directory, specified by -I
yourdir, relative to current working directory, specified by -I yourdir
Site- and release-specific C++ include file directories (CC command)
/usr/include/CC (CC command)
/usr/include

(cc, c99, CC, and cpp commands) Provides information about recompilation dependencies that the source file invokes on #include files and other source files. This information is printed in the form expected by . Such dependencies are introduced by #include directives. The output is directed to stdout.
(cc, c99, CC, and cpp commands) Enables the old style (referred to as KfoobarR) preprocessing. Use this option if you have problems with preprocessing (especially non-C source code).
The -nostdinc option stops the preprocessor from searching for include files in the standard directories (/usr/include/CC and /usr/include).

Removes any initial definition of macro. Any predefined macro, except those required by the C and C++ standards, can be undefined by the -U option. The -U option overrides the -D option if the same macro is specified for both, regardless of the order in which they appear on the command line. To undefine more than one macro, specify multiple -U options.
Macros defined in the standard headers are not predefined macros and are not affected by the -U option.

Identifies library files to be loaded. If libfile begins with a period (.) or slash (/), it is assumed to be a path name and is used without modification. An initial . (or ..) is interpreted as the current working directory (or its parent directory) and is not relative to the directory of the input file (if different from the current working directory). To specify more than one libfile, specify multiple -l options.

There is no search order for libraries. Default libraries are as follows:
libC.a (CC command)
libc.a
libfi.a
libu.a
libsma.a
libsci.a
libm.a
libf.a
If you specify personal libraries by using the -l command-line option, those libraries are added to the top of the preceding list.

CC, cc, c89, and c99 commands. Changes the -l option search algorithm to search directory libdir before searching the default directories. If libdir does not begin with a slash (/), it is interpreted as relative to the current working directory.
The loader searches for library files in the compiler release-specific directories.

note.para: Multiple -L options are treated cumulatively; that is, as if all libdir arguments appeared on one -L option preceding all -l options. Do not attempt to load functions of the same name from different libraries by using alternating -L and -l options.

listitem.para: Produces an absolute binary file named outfile. A file named a.out is produced by default. When this option is used in conjunction with the -c option and a single C or C++ source file, a relocatable object file named outfile is produced.
Produces executable files from which symbolic and other information that is not required for proper execution has been removed. Both the -g and -G options override -s.

Names the source files to be compiled or assembled. File suffixes and the commands that accept them are as follows: Command
File Suffix
CC
.c, .C, .i, .c++, .C++, .cc, .cxx, .CXX, .CC, and .cpp
cc and c99
.c and .i
c89
.c and .i
cpp
Accepts files with any suffix

The command mode option (-h command) allows you to create commands for foobar systems to supplement commands developed by Cray. Your command (a.out or outfile from the -o outfile option) will execute immediately on one SSP on the support node. The -h ssp option also creates an executable that runs on an SSP; however, the executable created via -h ssp runs on an application node. See foobar for more information on nodes.
For simplicity, you should use the C compiler to load your programs built with the command mode option, because the required options and libraries are automatically specified and loaded for you.

Programs linked with the -command loader option must be compiled with the -h command option. That is, do not link object files built with the command mode option with object files that do not use the option.

Decompiles (translates) the intermediate representation of the compiler into listings that resemble the format of the source code. You can use these files to examine the restructuring and optimization changes made by the compiler, which can lead to insights about changes you can make to your C or C++ source to improve its performance.
The compiler produces two decompilation listing files, with these extensions, per source file specified on the command line: .opt and .cg.

Changes the ident name to name. The default is the file name specified on the command line. name is used as the module name in the object file (.o suffix) and assembler (.s suffix) file. Regardless of whether name is specified or the default is used, the following transformations are performed on name:
All . characters in name are changed to $.
If the name starts with a number, a $ symbol is prepended to it.
The -h nombl options disable or enable the multiple program multiple data (MPMD) capability. For details, see foobar
The -h noomp options disable or enable the compiler recognition of OpenMP directives. For details, see foobar.

The -h predeclare_intrinsics option simulates the effect of including intrinsics.h at the beginning of a compilation. Use this option if the source code does not include the intrinsics.h statement and you cannot modify the code. This option is off by default.
The -h taskn option enables tasking in applications that contain OpenMP directives. The default is -h task0.
Description
Disables tasking. Characteristics include low compile time and size. OpenMP directives are ignored. The -h task0 option is compatible with all vectorization and scalar optimization levels.

The -h task1 option specifies user tasking, so OpenMP directives are recognized. Characteristics include low compile time and size. No level for scalar optimization is enabled automatically. The -h task1 option is compatible with all vectorization and scalar optimization levels.

Enables Unified Parallel C (UPC). UPC is a C language extension for parallel program development that allows you to explicitly specify parallel programming through language syntax rather than through library functions such as are used in MPI or SHMEM. For details on supported UPC functions, see the foobar.

(CC, cc, c99, and cpp commands) Displays compiler version information. If no source file is specified on the command line, no compilation occurs. Version information consists of the product name, the version number, and the current date and time.

(CC, cc, and c99 commands). Specifies the number of processing elements to use during execution. The npes argument specifies the number of processing elements and has no default value. It must be explicitly set to an integer value from 1 through 4096.
Once set, the number of processing elements to use cannot be changed at load or run time. You must recompile the program with a different value for npes to change the number of processing elements.
If you use the loader on a program compiled with the -X option, you must specify the same value to the loader as was specified at compile time.

refsect1.title: COMPILE TIME ENVIRONMENT VARIABLES
refsect1.para:
These environment variables are used during compilation. For run time and OpenMP environment variables, refer to the foobar. CRAYOLDCPPLIB
Allows, when set to a nonzero value, C++ code that uses the nonstandard headers files below to be compiled properly:
common.h
complex.h
fstream.h
generic.h
iomanip.h
iostream.h
stdiostream.h
stream.h
strstream.h
vector.h
If you want to use the standard C++ header files, your code may require modification to compile successfully. Refer to foobar.
Setting the CRAYOLDCPPLIB environment variable to a nonzero value disables exception handling. Refer to the -h [no]exceptions option.
See also the -h dep_name and -h parse_templates options.
CRI_CC_OPTIONS CRI_cc_OPTIONS CRI_c89_OPTIONS CRI_cpp_OPTIONS
(Note that the name of the appropriate command is included in the variable name.) Specifies command line options that are applied to all compilations. Options specified by this environment variable are added following the options specified directly on the command line. This is especially useful for adding options to compilations done with build tools.
LANG
Identifies your requirements for native language, local customs, and a coded character set with regard to compiler messages.
MSG_FORMAT
Controls the format in which you receive compiler messages.
NLSPATH
Specifies the message system catalogs that should be used.
NPROC
Specifies the number of processes used for simultaneous compilations. The default is 1. When more than one source file is specified on the command line, compilations may be multiprocessed by setting the environment variable NPROC to a value greater than 1. You can set NPROC to any value, but large values can overload the system.
TARGET
foobar Specifies type and characteristics of the hardware on which you are running. To cross compile source code for another Cray system, use the TARGET environment variable for that system.

refsect1.title: foobar
refsect1.para: By default, the compilation process creates an absolute binary file named a.out that reflects the contents of the source files and any referenced library functions. File a.out can then be executed on the target Cray system. The compiler commands accept several types of file arguments, as explained in the following paragraphs.

The cc, c89, and c99 commands interpret files with .c or .i suffixes as C source files. The CC command interprets files with .c, .i, .C, .c++, .C++, .cc, .cxx, .CXX, .CC, or .cpp suffixes as C++ source files. The source files are compiled, and each corresponding object code is left in a file whose name is that of the source, with .o substituted for the previous suffix. When no options are selected to control the compilation process, the CC, cc, and c99 commands automatically call the loader. The loader uses file.o as input and produces the executable file a.out.

Files whose names end with .s are interpreted as CAL source files. They are assembled, and each corresponding object code is left in a file. The file name is that of the source file, with .o substituted for .s. Again, the loader uses file.o as input and produces the executable file a.out.

Any compatible object files whose names end with .o, plus files whose names end with no suffix or a suffix other than those mentioned above (for example, file.a), are passed to the loader (in the order specified on the command line) to produce the a.out executable program.

With the use of appropriate options, compilation can be terminated early to produce one of several intermediate translations, including object files (-c option), assembly source expansions for C or C++ code (-S option), or the output of the preprocessor phase of the compiler (-P and -E options). In general, the intermediate files can be saved and later resubmitted to the cc, c89, c99, or CC command, with other files or libraries included as necessary.

Note that the CC command cannot be used to create a C file which represents the C++ source code. This is because the Cray C++ compiler does not translate C++ into an intermediate C form, but instead translates directly into machine code for the target machine.
